column1: Retinal artery occlusion is a blockage in one of the small arteries that carry blood to the retina.
Retinal arteries may become blocked when a blood clot or fat deposits get stuck in the arteries.
These blockages are more likely if there is hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis) in the eye.
The most common sources of clots are the heart and carotid artery in the neck.

Most blockages occur in people with conditions such as: - Carotid artery disease, in which the two large blood vessels in the neck become narrowed or blocked - Diabetes - Heart rhythm problem (atrial fibrillation) - Heart valve problem - High levels of fat in the blood (hyperlipidemia) - High blood pressure - Intravenous drug abuse - Temporal arteritis (damage to arteries due to an immune response) If a branch of the retinal artery is blocked, part of the retina will not receive enough blood and oxygen.
